DIV1.P: THE TRYALS OF TWO CAUSES, BETWEEN Theophilus Cibber, Gent.
PLAINTIFF, AND William Sloper, Esq DEFENDANT.
The FIRST for Criminal Conversation.
The SECOND, for detaining the Plaintiff's WIFE.
LONDON: Printed for T. TROTT, in Fleetstreet. 1740. (Price Six Pence.)

DIV1.HEAD: A SHORT ACCOUNT OF A TRIAL, &c.
DIV1.P: ON Tuesday the 4th of December, 1739, at nine o' Clock in the Morning, at the Sittings in the Court of King's Bench in Middlesex, before the Right Honourable Sir William Lee, Knt. Lord Chief Justice of that Court, came on a Trial by a Spe∣cial Jury of Gentlemen, of another Cause, in which Theophilus Cibber, Gent. was Plaintiff, and William Sloper, Esq was Defendant.

The Council for the Plaintiff, were Mr. Solli∣tor-General, Mr. Marsh, Mr. Bootle, Mr. Henley and Mr. Townshend. The Council for the De∣fendant were Mr. Lloyd, Mr. Clarke, Mr. Mur∣ray, Mr. Dennison, and Mr. Barnardiston.

Mr. Townshend, for the Plaintiff opened the Declaration, which was for Tresspass and Assault, in taking, leading away, and detaining the Plain∣tiff's
Wife; and again, for assaulting, beat∣ing, &c. the Plaintiff's Wife, whereby he lost her Assistance to his Damage of TEN THOU∣SAND POUNDS.

Mr. Sollicitor-General, (John Strange, Esq) stated the Case for the Plaintiff; and (among other Things) took Notice, “That there had been another Trial last Year, for a criminal Conversation, in which the Plaintiff had a Verdict: That it might have been reasonably expected the Defendant would have disconti∣nued his Acquaintance there; but it has un∣happily proved otherwise: She has been se∣creted from her Husband in an obscure Part of the World, Kennington-lane, never went abroad, and has been there visited by the Defendant Mr. Sloper: That after the former Verdict it could not be supposed they would act open∣ly, or unguardedly, to be as liable to a De∣tection, and manifest Proof: That the Declara∣tion therefore was only for detaining, &c. therefore this present Trial was not likely to afford so much Mirth and Entertainment to to the Bystanders as the former; but yet that they (viz. for the Plaintiff) should lay such an Evidence before the Jury, as should make it appear the Defendant did not keep her thus retired merely to look on: That if the Wo∣man had been left to the Influence and prope Expostulations of her Husband (who has been ready to forgive and cherish her) she migh have been reclaimed: but as the Defendant has not been deterred by the Verdict of las
Year, here appears no Remedy against this Conduct, except another Verdict for such Damages as may be a sufficient Warning to him; otherwise he may be willing to conti∣nue this Commerce at the Expence of sub∣mitting to small Damages and Costs yearly. That the Plaintiff in wanting the Assistance of his Wife, has lost her Salary of 200 l. ”a Year, and a Benefit worth 200 l. more.

Mr. Marsh, on the same Side, spoke to the same Purpose; and observed, that every Body who had seen Mrs. Cibber perform, must know that she is a Woman of an excellent Under∣standing, or she could never perform so well: That this good Sense of hers must have caused or revived a Compunction in her for the false Step she had made, and have induced her to have been all Duty and Obedience to her Hus∣band, and to have used double Diligence to have retrieved, or made some Amends for the Errors of her former Behaviour; if she had not been seduced by the Defendant, who it seems has too powerful an Influence over her.

Here Mrs. Bret was called to prove the Mar∣riage: But Col. Moreton, acquaintaing his Lord∣ship that he had some call of a publick Nature n another Place, was examined to Mr. Slo∣er's Declarations; but the Colonel knew not ny. The Defendant's Council also admitted the Marriage.
DIV1.STAGE: Mr. Smith of Kennington-lane was sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: Last April two Women took some Rooms of my Wife; a Gentlewoman came there to lodge two or three Days afterwards. The Servants Name was Allen, the Gentlewoman had lately lain in; and they said came there to drink Asses Milk, and she did drink Asses Milk.
What was their Agreement?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: I do not know. They made the Agreement with my Wife; she's here, she can tell.
When did Mrs. Cibber come to your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: She came two or three Days after they took the Lodging.
How long did they lodge at your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: About five Months; I cannot be certain, my Wife can tell.
What Name did she go by?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: [here he paused] I have forgot, my Wife can tell.
Did any Gentleman come to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: Yes.
What Name did he go by?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: [here he paused] He went by the Name of WHEELER.
How often did he come?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: Once a Fortnight; sometimes oft∣ner.
At what Time of the Day did he usually come?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: About two or three o' Clock; and sometimes staid till ten: I don't think he ever staid till eleven.
Where did they pass their Time?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: Sometimes they sat in the Dining-Room, sometimes they walked in the Garden, sometimes they sat with us.
Was there not a Bedchamber adjoining to that Dining-Room?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: Yes, but they always sat with the Door open, the Door was generally open; every one that went up Stairs or down could see 'em as they sat, and there was a Gentleman lodged next Room.
What Relation did you think there was between your Lodger and the Gentleman (whose Name you have forgot) that visited her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: We fancied them to be a new married Couple, that had a mind to keep it pri∣vate; but he passed for her Brother.
Then who was to be her Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: A Country Gentleman somewhere in the Country.
Whom do you now believe to be Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: When Mr. Cibber came, we be∣lieved Mr. Cibber to be her Husband.
[by the Defendant's Council] When Mr. Cib∣ber came, what did he do?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Smith.
SP.P: He brought two or three Men a∣long with him, and took some of her Things a∣way.

DIV1.P: She gave in Substance the same Account as her Husband had done, with this farther; That upon the taking her Lodgings, she [the Witness] had caused Enquiry to be made at the former Lodgings in Devonshire-Street, where they said, they could assure her, that the Gentlewoman was a mar∣ried Woman. This Witness also remembred that Mrs Cibber went by the Name of Archer; that the Witness's Daughter commonly marketted for her, and had the Money from Mrs Allen.

SP.P: Has Mr Wheeler, or Mr Sloper been at your House since Mr Cibber was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Smith.
SP.P: He has called there twice: The first Time was about three or four Months ago; the last Time about a Fortnight or three Weeks since.
What did he say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Smith.
SP.P: The last Time he said Mr Cibber had brought an Action against him; and asked if we could say any harm of him.

DIV1.P:
She confirmed what her Father and Mother had sworn, and gave an account of the taking the Lodging, and of Mrs Cibber's coming there with a Maid (Mrs Allen,) and a Nurse and Child about two Months old, named Mary: She described two Gardens belonging to the House, with a Sum∣mer-house and Arbour in them, which were all within the View of ten or twelve Windows of the House, from whence every Thing could be seen
that was done: That one Mr Shaw a Surgeon, came there and fancied he knew Mrs Cibber. She also said, that she saw Mrs Archer write in a Book, which (she believes) was the same which was pro∣duced to her at the Trial: That the Child had the Small-pox and was attended by Mr Blisset, an A∣pothecary; that in a few Days after Mr Shaw had been there, Mr Cibber came; and the next Day af∣ter Mr Cibber had been there, Mrs Cibber went away.

He agreed with the other Witnesses, with this: I can give no Account of the Times of the Gentle∣man's coming to visit, because I generally spent all the Day in the City: Sometimes when I came home at Night, I found him there; and he went away usually at ten at Night: I am sure he never staid later than eleven. [Being asked as to his Opi∣nion,] At first, by Reason of his frequent coming, I believed he was a young Gentleman of Fortune who had married her unknown to his Relations; but afterwards I began to alter my Opinion, because he never lay in the House. Gentlemen, you may remember a Night of terrible Thunder and Light∣ning last Summer, he happened to be there that Night, he went away in the Midst of that Wea∣ther, though we press'd him to stay, and offered to get ready a Bed for him, but he went away, and I lent him my Great Coat.

This Witness gave an Account, how the Clerk of the Plaintiff's Attorney came there
lately to make enquiry, personating the Defen∣dant's Attorney, which the Court declared to be a foul Piece of Practice. The Plaintiff's Attor∣ney said it was done without any Order from him, he knew nothing of it.
Watson sworn and examined; and Cross exami∣ned, said

I am a Shoemaker. I went along with Mr Cibber. He went up Stairs directly. He said he came to de∣mand his Wife, she promised to go. He took some Linnen and Apparrel; she was in Bed, but we went out of the Room 'till she was dress'd. He said he was to dine at the Rummer Tavern at two o'clock, and desired her to come to him there, and said she should never want a Shilling while he had it. She promised so to do. He took her Purse, in which there was eighteen Pence and a Pocket-piece, but he threw it back; he had her Watch, 'twas a Silver Watch.
Mr Campbell (the Defendant's Banker) was sworn.

The Account Book was shewn to him, he never had seen the Defendant write, any more than his Name several times, but had some Letters from him. This Witness believed divers short Entries in the Account Book to be the Defendant's Hand writing, as Account at Mrs Smith's, April 19th.— Allen having 20 Guineas in Hand.—Left in Allen' Hand 50 Guineas.— Brought forward. —
Mr Arne (Mrs Cibber's Brother) being sworn, proved her Hand-writing in the Book.

I live in Devonshire-Street, Mrs Archer (whom I since hear to be Mrs Cibber) came to lodge at my House the 12th of January last, and staid there 14 Weeks all but a Day; A Gentleman came too see her sometimes, but I never knew his Name; she never went abroad all the Time; she was brought to bed there; the Christening was abroad; she had her Maid Mrs Allen, and a Wet-nurse, and a Nurse who set up with her the whole Month. She was brought to Bed on the 26th of February; they had the Dining-room and Bedchamber, and Rooms up two Pair of Stairs; the Rent was Twenty-six Shil∣lings a Week, and was paid monthly by Mrs Allen till the last Time. She was recommended to me as the Wife of a Country Gentleman. I heard the Nurses had three Guineas each at the Christening, and that the Christening cost ten Guineas.
This Witness had a Crown from Mrs Archer in Devonshire-Street, as Servant there. Note, there was n Entry in the Book of five Shillings to Mrs Bishop.
Mr Rich and Milward being severally sworn, proved that Mrs Cibber could have Two Hundred Pounds a Year Salary; and that her Benefit might e worth One Hundred Pounds.
There were other Witnesses examined to shew that the Plaintiff and his Wife had formerly lived in Harmony.
The Defendant's Council observed upon the E∣vidence, that the Plaintiff did not come for his Wife, but to strip her of what he could find. Why did he not take her along with him?

In reply to this, the Plaintiff's Council shewed that the Plaintiff was at that Time under a Recog∣nizance for the Peace and Behaviour to her; and that if he should attempt to compel her to go along with him, he might be in Danger of forfeiting his Recognizance.
After hearing his Lordship's Charge, the Jury went out, and in less than half an Hour, found a Verdict for the Plaintiff, and Five Hundred Pound Damages.

DIV1.HEAD: THE TRYAL, &c.
DIV1.P: ON Tuesday the 5th of December, 1738, at Nine o'Clock in the Morning, at the Sittings in the Court of King's-Bench in Middlesex, before the Right Hon. Sir William Lee, Knt. Lord Chief Justice of that Court, came on the remarkable Trial before a Special Jury of Gentlemen of a Cause in which Theophilus Cibber, Gent. was Plaintiff, and William Sloper, Esq was Defendant.

The Declaration (which was opened by the unior Council for the Plaintiff) was for As∣aulting, Ravishing, and Carnally Knowing Su∣annah Maria Cibber, the Plaintiff's Wife: And his was laid, to be done at three several Pe∣iods of Time, at divers Days between such Day, to such a Day, at each Period; where∣y (the Declaration said) the Plaintiff lost the Company, Comfort, Society, Assistance, &c. f his Wife, to his Damage of FIVE THOUSAND POUNDS.

The Council for t Plaintiff were, Mr Sollicitor General, Mr Hollings, Serjeant Agar, Mr. Marsh, Mr Dernison, and Mr Lawson. The Council for the Defendant were Serjeant Eyre, Mr Noel, Mr Lloyd, Mr Murray, and Mr Barnadiston.

It is here proper to let the Reader understand that this Tryal is not taken in the very Words at Length: as is sometimes done, when a Short∣hand Writer can be conveniently placed. But the Person who attended on this Occasion was at such Disadvantage, that he was forced to take it in an abridged Way; writing down the Substance of it as well as he could: W thought good to mention this, that we may not be understood to impose on our Readers nor to injure the great Men concerned: W therefore hope that neither the learned Gen∣tlemen at the Bar, nor the Court, will be of¦fended, that we cannot do them full Justice i Printing at Length the very good Argument on both Sides, and his Lordship's excellen Charge to the Jury.

Mr Sollicitor General, (— Strange, Esq Stated the Case for the Plaintiff; and (amon many other things) observed to the Court an the Jury, that the Injury done to the Plainti was of the most tender Concern to his Peace o Mind, Happiness, and Hopes of Posterity, an was the highest of all Injuries for which h could come before them to seek a Recompenc or Satisfaction in Damages; and that indee
it was impossible to give a pecuniary Satisfac∣tion adequate to the Injury: For that no Sum of Money could restore a Man's Tranquility of Mind. But that the Plaintiff must rest up∣on such Remedy as the Law had given him.

He farther observed (upon the Plaintiff's be∣ing a Player) that 'tis true the Plaintiff was a Player, but he was also a Gentleman; being well descended and having had a liberal Edu∣cation; that the Plaintiff himself was a very good Player; that his Father-was well known o all Gentlemen, who delighted in Theatrical Entertainments to be of the first Figure in that Profession, and an Author too; that the Plain∣iff's Grandfather was the best Statuary of his Time; and that the Plaintiff by the Mother's Side, was related to William of Wickham: and n right of that Pedigree, had received his Edu∣cation upon a Foundation of that great Man.

He said he knew it was attempted by ome, to have the Players considered in a Mat∣er of this Nature, as not upon the same ooting with the rest of the Subjects; as if it were more lawful to invade their Properties, han those of other People; but he knew no aw that deprived them of those Comforts, or f those Rights which other Subjects ought to njoy: That the Stage had been cherished nd encouraged by the Politest and Wisest tates, as a School of Virtue and good Morals; nd that many received good Lessons and Im∣ressions from what they hear at the Theatre;
who perhaps don't incline to go seek for In∣struction elsewhere.

That there had been a good deal of Pains taken to spread a Report about Town as if the Plaintiff had been consenting to the Wrong the Defendant had done him; but this was only to blast the Credit of the Plaintiff's Cause be∣fore the Trial; and that it might come with Prejudice before the Jury. That his Brief in∣structed him, that there could not be the least Colour or Shadow of Proof to support such a Surmise.

Mr Sollicitor General also Stated the Evi¦dence for the Plaintiff, in part as it comes from the Plaintiff's Witnesses in the following Pages but as to part of what comes from Mr Carte of Kensington, it doubtless was never mentio∣ned in his Brief. As to the principal Facts h mentioned, the Witness Mr Hayes's looking through a Hole in a Wainscoat Partition which parted Mr Hayes's Closet from a Roo in which the Defendant and Mrs Cibber wer together; and that through that Hole M Hayes at several different Days and Time saw them guilty of Criminal Familiarities, an in such Acts, and with such Circumstances and particularly the last Time, he, Mr Haye saw such a Sight, as he (Mr Sollicitor) woul leave to the Witness to tell; for it ought t be related but once.

Mr Hollings also spoke very well on th same Side, pathetically observing to the Gen¦tlemen
of the Jury the mischievous Conse∣quence of Suffering a Man to commit such an Injury to the married State without being o∣bliged to repair it in Damages; that the Plain∣tiff was an Englishman, and as such, had Rights which ought not to be invaded, parti∣cularly in the present Instance; that he had brought his Complaint before a Jury of English Gentlemen, and he (Mr Hollings) did not doubt, that they would give the Plaintiff pro∣per Damages.
The Plaintiff's Council then proceeded to call their Witnesses: And First, to prove the Marriage between the Plaintiff and his Wife, hey called Mrs Brett, but she did not appear t this time.
DIV1.Q: Note, She appeared in the Afternoon, as will be mentioned hereafter.
DIV1.STAGE: The Plaintiff's Attorney then named Mr Cib∣ber, the Plaintiff's Father, who being pre∣sent in Court, was sworn. His Evidence was in Substance as follows:

SP.P: Do you know of the Plaintiff's being married to his present Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: I was not at the Marriage, but am as well convinced that they were married, s that I my self was married. I was against he Match.
Why where you against the Match?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: Because She had no Fortune.
Did they at first live happily together?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: They did live happy, very hap∣py, much happier than I expected; for I wa averse to the Match.
How long did they live thus happily to∣gether.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: About three Years; within tha Time they had two Children, which are both dead.
Did Mr Cibber, the Plaintiff, during tha time support her well and liberally, as became an affectionate Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: He did, even to Profusion. often admonished him about it; and advised him to retrench his Expences; for I though them a good deal too large for his Condition, or what he was able to afford. He made he several valuable Presents of Rings and Jewels.
Is not Mrs Cibber a good Actress? and how did she become so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: When they married She was a Singer, but there were better Voices. I though her Voice not the best; and if not best, 'ti nothing. I thought it might possibly do bet∣ter for speaking. I asked her Husband if he had ever heard her attempt to speak a Part he said he had; and that she did it very pret∣tily. I tried her, and was much surprized to find her do it so very well.
Did not her Husband take Pains to in∣struct her?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P:
I believe I was the Person who chiefly instructed her; I spent a good deal o
Time, and took great Delight in it: for she was ery capable of receiving Instruction. In Forty ears Experience that I have known the Stage, never knew a Woman at the beginning so pable of the Business, or improve so fast.
When did you first here of any Disagree∣ent in the Family?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Cibber.
SP.P: Soon after he came from France; bout last April.

DIV1.STAGE: Mr Fleetwood, Master of Drury-lane Play∣house was sworn.

SP.P: Sir, Do you know the Plaintiff's Wife? s she a good Player.
Yes, Sir, I think her a good layer for her Time.
What Salary did you give her? What dvantages did she bring to her Husband?
She played three Seasons: or the first, her Salary was an hundred Pounds, nd she had a Benefit.
What was that Benefit worth?

I can't be particular, because have not looked into the Accounts on this Occasion. If I had known I should have been xamined to this, I could have been particular. believe it might be about a hundred Pound.
Well, Sir, the second Year?
The second Year, Sir, I gave er two hundred Pounds Salary, and she had a enefit.
What was that Benefit worth?
That must have been a good deal better than an hundred Pound.
Then the third Year?
Her Salary the third Year wa two hundred Pound, and she had a Benefit.
What was that worth?
I believe it must have bee worth an hundred and fifty Pound; for sh grew much in the Favour of the Town, an 'twas a very good Benefit.
SP.Q: Note, The Examination to these Matter was at first opposed by the Defendant Council, as not being supported by the De¦claration; but the Plaintiff's Counc insisted, that it being laid in the Decla¦ration, that by the Means there alledge the Plaintiff had lost the Assistance o his Wife, he had a Right to prove t Loss he sustained by the Defendant taking her off the Stage, and the Qua¦tum of that Loss. And of that Opinio was the Court: so Mr Fleetwood w examined as above. The Defendant Council insisted that nothing here appear¦ed that the Defendant had taken her o the Stage, and they Cross-Examine Mr Fleetwood.

SP.P: Sir, how comes it that Mrs Cibber do not play this Season?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Fleetwood.
SP.P: Because we could not agree pon the Terms. I would not come up to her Terms.
What were her Terms?
She insisted to have as good Salary as any Woman in the House; and the rst Benefit.
Perhaps she deserves as much; is she not s good a Player as any in the House?
I can't say that, I can't pre∣end to determine that. I have got more Mo∣ey by Mrs Clive.
Mr Quin, Mr Johnson, and some others ere called for this Purpose; but the Court was 'Opinion, 'twas now proper fr the Plaintiff's ouncil to establish their principal Fact.
Mrs Hayes, pray give my Lord and the ry an Account of the Defendant's and Mrs bber's coming to your House. Do you know rs Hopson?

Yes, Sir, it was just this Day welve-month, the fifth of December, that rs Hopson came into my Lodgings. I live in ue-cross-street, Leicester-fields; on the Satur∣ Mrs Hopson came to my House and took Lodgings; she beat them down as low as could, for she said she was a single Wo∣n, and should give but very little Trouble, had no body to come after her but a Gen∣tleman
and a Gantlewoman that would come to see her sometimes. She had the Lodgings for seven Shillings a Week; two Rooms on the first Floor; there was a Bed in each of them one of the Beds was a Turn-up Bed. She wa to come in on Sunday, but she sent me Wor that she should not come in 'till Monday, an on Monday, the fifth of December, she came i a Hackney-Coach, and some Boxes and Thing with her. On Sunday in the Evening a youn Gentleman, whom I afterwards knew to b Mr Sloper, called and asked if Mrs Hopson ha not taken the Lodgings, and whether she w come: We told him she had taken the Lod¦ings, but that she had sent Word that s should not come till Monday. She lay there Monday Night. Neither Mrs Cibber nor Sloper came that Day, but they came soon a¦ter, I think 'twas on Tuesday, and they supp together, and went away between eleven a twelve o'Clock; Mrs Hopson sat up, and them out, and locked the Door after the They often came in the Space of six We that Mrs Hopson had the Lodgings; I beli near Twenty Times. They did not come ¦gether, but dropping in one after the oth They sometimes dined, but most commo supped there. Mrs Hopson used to leave th together every Time they came; sometimes Hour, sometimes two or three Hours at a ti She often made Errants to go out to buy so¦thing; and sometimes sat two Hours at a
below Stairs with me, while they were above ogether. They stay'd sometimes till One or wo o'Clock in the Morning; and how they ent away I cannot tell, for I was in Bed at se Times, but I believe they usually went Chairs or Coaches.
When they were thus left alone, did hey use to fasten the Door?
Yes, the Door used to be fast? Mrs Hopson used to go and knock at it, and hey let her in; and sometimes she could not et in, and use to come down Stairs again.
How did you know they were Mr Sloper nd Mrs Cibber?

There was an Acquaintance of ine at my House one Day, when Mrs Hop∣n came down Stairs to me; one Mr Rowe, nd he knew Mrs Hopson; How do you do rs Hopson? said he. So after she was gone, asked him who Mrs Hopson was, and he told e she was Mrs Cibber's Maid; so I gave er Warning, and let my Lodgings to another; er I did not like their coming. Mrs Hopson did ot usually lye there o'Nights, except when they ad been there in the Evening; but on those ights she did lie there. One Day after I ve Warning, Mr Sloper was in a great Pas∣on above Stairs at something, and Mrs Hopson me to me, You have made a fine Kettle of ish of it, says she. I did not know what she eant by her Kettle of Fish. What Fish do you can? says I. Why there, says she, you have been
talking of Matters, and he's stark mad at it ¦bove Stairs. She would have kept the Lo¦gings; but I chose not. I let them to anothe and so they went away.
Did Mr Cibber ever call at your Hou and talk with you about them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Hayes.
SP.P: Yes, about five or six Mont ago, he came and asked me, if Mrs Hopson h not lodged there? I told him she had. asked who came to see her, and I describ them, both by their Clothes and their Person so he said no more, and went away.
Sir, give an Account of Mrs Hops lodging at your House, and who came to her, and what happened, &c.

When Mrs Hopson had Lodgings, Mr Sloper and Mrs Cibber used come often to her, and she used to leave th together two or three Hours at a Time. Th used to go away at one, two, or three o'Clo in the Morning, in Coaches or in Chairs. have a Closet on the same Floor, adjoin to the Room where they used to fit; I bo Holes through the Wainscoat, and could them very plain. He used to kiss her, and her on his Lap. On the 22d Day of Dece¦ber I was looking through; he took her on Knee, lifted up her Clothes, and took do his Breeches, and took his privy Member a
it in his Hand, and put it between her s. On the 12th Day of January, I was k'd up in the Closet at one o'Clock in the ernoon; and he came first, and he was an∣, because she was not come, and he sent s Hopson for her. In about two Hours she e. Mrs Hopson went away, and left them e: So he spoke something to her in an angry about Mr Fleetwood; she said she would away her Brother from his House, and she did not value Mr Fleetwood. He and grew Friends again; they made it up, and ook her upon his Lap, took up her Clothes, k down his Breeches, and put his pri∣ Member between her Legs. I stayed there ger. Between five and six in the Evening et down the Turn-up Bed softly, she laid self upon it, upon her Back, and pulled up Clothes; her Body was bare. He unbut∣ed his Clothes, hung his Bag-wig upon a nce, let down his Breeches, took his privy mber in his Hand, and lay down upon her. Hereupon some further Questions offered as he Fact, his Lordship interposed to this Ef∣; there is no occasion to be more particular; are not trying a Rape. However the Wit∣ did say there was a Criminal Conversation, being a Foreigner, he express'd himself as ch by Gestures, as by Words.
Was their Chamber Lock'd?
No, it was fastened with Screw. The Holes are there to be seen in th Wainscoat and the Door.
Who did that Screw belong to?
I believe it was Mrs Hopson I have seen it lying in the Chamber Window
How did you know who they were?

Mr Rowe was one Day at o House, and he spoke to Mrs Hopson; and a¦terwards he said, she was Mrs Cibber's Ma Besides I dogged them both Home in th Chairs: Her Chair carried her to Mr Cibber House, Number 12, in little Wild-Court, a his Chair went to his Father's House in James's Place. After he was gone into House, I ask'd the Chairmen whose H that was? and they told me old Mr Slope I had often seen him at the Tennis-Court, knew his Name there.

I was one Day at Mr Hayes's, and Hopson came in, I asked how she did? I known her for a good many Years before; the last time I had seen her, I had been she lived with Mr Cibber. I believe I told Hayes so.

My Lord we would beg L to call back the last Witness (Mr Hayes ask him this Question? Why he took Pains to Dog Mr Sloper's Chair, at that
of Night, to learn who he was, when he had known him before at the Tennis-Court?
Mr Hayes being called in again, and the Question put to him; he answered to this Pur∣pose?

As Mr Sloper and Mrs Cibber came into my House, I knew them both, because I had seen him at the Tennis-Court, and her on the Stage; but to be the more certain, I went and followed their Chairs, as I told you.
Give an Account of Mr Cibber and Mrs Cibber's Lodging at your House in March last, and whether Mr Sloper resorted there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr Carter.
SP.P: Yes Sir, on the Second of March Mrs Cibber took the Lodgings, I believe for hem all; there were three Beds.
Do you remember any thing of Mr Cib∣ber's going to France, and whether Mr Sloper came there during his Abscence.

Yes, Mr Cibber went to France soon fter, and Mr Sloper did lodge there part of the ime while he was abscent; and he lodged there gain soon after Mr Cibber came back; and there was a Lodging taken for Mr Cibber, at Blue-Green, bout a Mile and a Half from Kensington, and fter Mr Cibber, Mrs Cibber, and Mr Sloper had upped together, Mr Cibber had a Man with a anthorn and Candle, between Nine and Ten Clock at Night, to light him to Blue-Green.
He came back to Breakfast next Morning, and every Morning; and they Dined and some∣times Supped together; and he went to Blue-Green at Night; and Mr Sloper, and Mrs Cibber lay at my House, but I do not know what Beds they lay in. When Mr Sloper went away from my House, back to London, Mr Cibber left Blue-Green, and came and lay a my House.
Who bore the Expences of their House∣keeping.
Mr Sloper did. Sometimes he gave my Wife Money to lay out; at othe times, my Wife laid out what was necessary and made a Bill of it, and Mr Sloper paid it.
Did Mr Cibber know this?
Yes Sir, it was very often be¦fore his Face.
Did he offer to pay any thing?
No Sir.
Hannah Calcot, and Ruth Calcot, being seve¦rally sworn and examined, had little to say.

They lived at Burnham in Buckinghamshir where Mr Sloper and Mrs Cibber spent pa of last Summer. They did not live in the F¦mily. The Amount of their Evidence wa that Mr Sloper and Mrs Cibber lived at th same House at Burnham; they were sure lived there because they had seen him walk a¦broad in his Slippers, and in an Undress.

Mr Fife, 'tis said, is a Serjeant in the Guards. Fife and Watson being severally sworn: depo∣sed, That they and another in a Coach went with Mr Cibber to Burnham in September last, to take away Mrs Cibber; that they left the Coach in a Field and went to the House where she and Mr Sloper were; that she was in a Night-gown sitting at the Tea-Table, and Mr Sloper was at the other side of it, in his Slippers; that Mr Cibber said he came to demand his Wife; that Mr Sloper cursed, and swore, and called Mr Cibber hard Names, but suffered one of the Witnesses to lead her to the Coach, and walk∣ed on the other side of her himself; that she gave him a Watch out of her Pocket; on which he said by G — well remembred, the Rascal would have had it else. That they drove away with Mrs Cibber in the Coach, along with Mr Cibber and two of his Assistants, the third be∣ng on Horseback. That Mr Sloper soon over∣took them; that he was Booted and on Horse∣back; that he swore there was a Villain in that Coach, who should never live to go into another: hat they came to Slough; and there Mrs Cibber not being well, desired Mr Sloper (who was at the side of the Coach, before the Door of the nn) to get her a Dram, that Mr Sloper brought her a Glass of Rum. That she was above a Quarter of an Hour in the Coach at the Door
of the Inn, while Mr Cibber was in the House providing for her Accommodation. That when Mr Cibber was in the Chamber in the Inn, she called her Husband a great many Villains, and said, that now he had ruined her Reputation: She did not value if all the World knew that she was with Child by 'Squire Sloper, and that she loved him dearly, for he was an honourable Gentle∣man; that Mr Sloper took up a Room in the Inn for some time, swore much, and fired a Pistol; which one of the Witnesses seemed willing to believe was intended at him; but being cross-examined, he did own, that the Muzzle of it was elevated, so as to point over the Stable; and also that Mr Cibber and his Assistants had two Case of Pistols loaded. These proved that Mr Sloper went away in the Night-time from the Inn, which determi∣ned Mr Cibber to stay all Night; that he sat up all Night himself; and procured a Woman to lye in the Bed with his Wife. She would eat no Supper though there was one provided; for she was Sulky. The next Day he did not take the direct Road to London, but drove a∣cross part of the Country and got to London in the Evening.

— Stint We hear that Mr Stint is a Candle-Snuffer at the Play-house.. Mr Cibber employed me to take care of his Wife when he brought her to Town, that she might not be taken away a∣gain, and he used her, and provided for her very honourably, and gave Orders at the Ta∣vern, the Bull-head, near Clare-Market, that she should want for nothing; Meat was dressed there for her, and brought to her, and Wine, a Pint of White and a Pint of Red. She com∣plained that it was cold Weather, and I made her a Fire, and locked her up in the Room, but she knocked and called, and begged for God's Sake I would let her out, or else she should be Stifled, for the Chimney Smoaked. So I let her out, and put out the Fire. Mr Thomas Arne, her Brother, came there, and he begged and prayed that I would let her go a∣long with him; but I would not break my Trust, I could not do it: He came several times, and finding I would not do it, began to break open the House, and at the same time bid her ry out Murder; she cried out Murder, and I believe there was an hundred Mob assisting him o break open the House. I had a Case of Pis∣ols, and laid my Back against the Door; but hey were too strong for me, and took my
Pistols out of each Hand, and held me fast by each Arm; and beat me severely, and tore all the Clothes off my Back, and took Mrs Cibber away with them.

This Witness proved that he was hired to carry two Ladies and a Gentleman, sometime in September last from Slough to Reading. He was to meet them at Slough, and met them accordingly. The Gentleman walked out of Town in his Boots, about half an Hour before the Coach, and when the Witness overtook him, he took him in: He knew neither him nor the Women.
This Witness was paid two Guineas for his Charges; and several other Witnesses, from Slough were also paid, who had nothing to say to the Purpose.
She proved the Marriage; and being asked when and where she saw Mrs Cibber last; She answered, this Morning, at her Mother's.
This last Question was asked because it had been insinuated that Mrs Cibber at that very time cohabited with Mr Sloper.

Mr Lloyd, on the same Side, made an excel∣lent Speech, which we do not take upon us to give the Reader; we shall only mention a Hint or two. He hoped (as Mr Serjeant Eyre had done) that nothing Criminal had passed between the Defendant and the Plaintiff's Wife; but if any thing seemed to tend that way, it at the same time appeared, that the
Plaintiff was privy and consenting to whatever ntercourse or Familiarities there passed between hem. That if there had been any thing done miss with such Circumstances (he submitted o his Lordship's Direction, but) apprehended hat the Plaintiff had no Wrong done him, up∣n this Maxim in Law and Reason, Volenti on fit injuria; and that therefore he (the Plaintiff) ought not to have a Verdict. But hat if it should be thought proper (notwith∣tanding such Consent) to find a Verdict for the Plaintiff, it would at least be fit and necessary or the Gentlemen of the Jury to proportion it o the Size of the Trespass, which he hoped would be taken in Consideration upon this Oc∣asion. — He said this and much more, in much better manner than we can relate it for a Reason already given) and proceeded to e Evidence for the Defendant.
Did you lodge at Mr Hayes's about this me Twelve-month?
Yes, Sir, I was then out of ervice. I had left Mr Cibber's; and intended o follow the Business of Mantua-making: I as bred to it.
Did Mr Sloper and Mrs Cibber some∣mes meet at your Lodgings?
Yes, they came to see me pret∣ty often. They desired they might come there, and usually had a bit of something for Supper.
For what Purpose did they meet?
As they were Acquaintance, to converse together.
Did you use to go out, and leave them alone together?
Yes, I often had occasion to go and buy something for Supper, or some Tea and Sugar; and I had occasion to be below Stairs to get Supper ready.
When you came up Stairs did you use t find the Chamber-door fast?
Sometimes it was so; and M Sloper used to open it to me.
Pray what could you believe was the Oc¦casion of these private Meetings.

I will tell you all I know o the Matter. I do not fear my Character; ther are enough in Court that will give me a ver good Character. It was about March wa Twelve-month that Mr Sloper used first t come to our House to Mr Cibber's: The Ser¦vants did not know who he was; but my Ma¦ster called him Mr Benefit, and used to say h was a Romp, and a good-natured Boy. Mr Cib¦ber was then very bare of Money, and afrai of his Creditors. I was very sorry for it; s he owed me a good deal of Money, and do so still. But one Day he told me: Anne, say he, I shall have a good deal of Money soo
and you shall have some. And I know he soon after had a good deal of Money, and he paid me five Guineas. That Summer we went to lodge at Kingston, and Mr Sloper with us. My Master used often to leave Mr Sloper and my Mistress at Home, and go a Riding or Abroad, some where or other. The rest of the Servants wondered at it as well as I; but I knew no Harm. They did not know Mr Slo∣per's Name. My Master called him his Cousin Thompson. Afterwards when they came to Town, I left the Service, and took that Lodg∣ing. In last Spring, about March last, I lived with them again. My Master took me aside, and made me promise Secrecy concerning some∣thing he was about to say to me. He told me he was going to France: That there was an Affair between Mr Sloper and his Wife: That he was ruined for ever if it should be publickly known. And he made me promise to live with her till he should come back, that the rest of the Servants might not know any thing of the Matter. I promised him. They took Lodg∣ings at Kensington, and my Master went to France in March or April. He was some Weeks gone, and in his Abscence Mr Sloper was commonly at the Lodgings at Kensington. When my Master came back he was at a Bag∣io in Goodman's Fields, and sent Word to my Mistress. Mr Sloper was not then at Kensing∣ton. My Mistress and I went to Goodman's Fields in a Hackney Coach, and he came back
with us to Kensington. In our Return w changed our Coach two or three times by th Way, that he might not be discovered. Sh told him, she expected Mr Sloper in a Day o two. My Master said he would take a Lodg¦ing when Mr Sloper came; or if there was no time for that, he would go lie at some Inn i the Town. Within two or three Days Mr Slo¦per came; and then Mr Cibber sent and took a Lodging at Blue-Green, and after Supper about nine or ten o'Clock he went there, with a Ma carrying a Lanthorn and Candle, and left Mr Cibber and Mr Sloper at the Lodgings at Ken∣sington. He came back to Breakfast nex morning, and dined, and I believe supped; and so he did several Days, till Mr Sloper went a∣way; and then Mr Cibber paid off the Lod∣gings at Blue-Green, and came to the Lod∣gings in Kensington to his Wife.
Was you at Burnham with Mr Cibber and his Wife, and Mr Sloper?

Yes, last Summer it was. They three and I looked over the House; that they might contrive in what Rooms to lie, and the rest of the Servants know nothing of the Affair It was a large House, seven Rooms on a Floor Mr Cibber's Bedchamber and Mr Sloper's had a Door opened between them. Mrs Cibber used to undress herself in my Master's Room, and leave her Clothes there, and put on a Bed∣gown, and take away one of the Pillows from my Master's Bed, and go away to Mr Sloper's
Room; my Master used to shut the Door af∣ter, her and say, Good Night my Dear; and sometimes he used to knock at their Door in a morning, to call them up to Breakfast, and at other Times he sent me to call them; and the Pillow was brought back again; for my Ma∣ster's Bed was always made with the two Pil∣ows.
Did you see Mrs Cibber the Day she was escued, and where?
Yes, I saw her at her Mother's, Mrs Arne's.
Was Mr Sloper there?
He was there.
What became of Mrs Cibber?
I do not know. She went way somewhere. I did not see her till two or three Days afterwards.
Did you go down into the Country with er afterwards.
Yes, we went to Reading. Mr Sloper met us at Slough, and there we went into the Reading Coach, Mr Sloper walked out some time before us, and the Coach took him up.
Where was Mrs Cibber afterwards?
At Reading with Mr Sloper, ll she came to Town about five Weeks ago?
SP.STAGE: Mrs Carter, (the Wife of a former Witness) was sworn.
SP.P: She gave in Substance the same Evidence that her Husband did before; and that Mr Sloper used to pay her the Money for House∣keeping. That when the Lodging was taken at Blue-Green, and upon her asking the mean∣ing of it, she had for Answer, 'twas because Mr Cibber was a mean spirited Dog.
Why would you keep such a House?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Carter.
SP.P: I thought it no Business of mine if the Husband consented, and was satisfied.
Give the Court, &c.

I lived at Burnham, an used to make the Beds. Mr Cibber and M Sloper's Beds. There were two Pillows o Mr Cibber's Bed, and only one Pillow o Mr Sloper's; but there was the mark of onl one Person having lain in Mr Cibber's Bed and of two in Mr Sloper's. The Bed-cham∣bers opened into each other: I never saw M Cibber undress; nor do not know who brought back the Pillow every morning.
As hath been said with regard the rest of th Council, so as to Mr Murray, we shall men∣tion but a few hints from his Speech.

He observed that the Plaintiff by his Coun∣cil shewed himself related to William of Wic¦ham;
but would have been better entitled to laim that Alliance if he had observed William of Wickham's Motto, that Morals make the Man. The Words are Manners make the Man; but Manners are there intended to sig∣ify Morals.

That upon the whole of the Evidence, (he he Council) was afraid that the Plaintiff's Wife and the Defendant had gone beyond the ounds of Duty; but whatever had passed, ppeared not only to have been with the Plain∣ff's Consent, but even to have been concert∣d by him. That the Defendant was a young entleman of Fortune, who became acquaint∣d with a Player and his Wife: That she being distress of the alluring Arts of the Stage, first gages the young Gentleman's Affection and aws him in, and this with the Husband's tivity and Assistance. For the Plaintiff conceals e Defendant's true Name from the Know∣dge of the Servants; at one place he calls him ousin Thompson; at another, Mr Benefit; a t Name, taken from a particular Night in e Year when they get a great deal of money. he Plaintiff tells the Servants the Defendant a Romp, and a good natur'd Boy; and he akes a Boy of him. He takes his Money, s him maintain his Family, resigns his Wife him; and then comes to a Court of Justice, d to a Jury of Gentlemen for Reparation in amages. The Council further represented, at it would be of the utmost ill Consequence,
if it should once come to be understood in the World, that two artful People, being Husband and Wife, might lay a Snare for the Affection of an unwary young Gentleman, take a Su of Money from him, and when he woul part with no more, then come for a secon Sum to a Court of Justice.

That he (the Council) desired to be un∣derstood as by no means an Advocate for th Immorality of the Action; but this is not Prosecution for the Publick, or to punish th Immorality: This is only a Question whether the Defendant has injur'd the Plaintiff; and certainly the Plaintiff cannot be injured, if h has not only consented, but has even taken Price.
However if it should be thought requisit to find a Verdict for the Plaintiff; we had not a Denomination of Coin small enough to be given him in Damages.
Mr Sollicitor General in his Reply, observe the ill Consequence of letting it pass for a La that Men might sell their Wives, which wo be the Consequence of giving a Verdict the Defendant.
His Lordship summed up the Evidence,
And the Jury withdrew, and in about h an Hour, brought in a Verdict for the Pla∣tiff, and Ten Pounds Damages.
